title: Pick the repository and base branch when assigning issues to Copilot
content: We're bringing you a range of additional options for assigning Copilot to issues as part of this public preview. When assigning an issue to Copilot coding agent, you can now choose which repository Copilot should work in, pick a starting branch, and provide additional instructions to give it more context. CCA.issue.assign.mp4 Here’s what’s new: Start Copilot assignment in one click: Assign tasks directly to Copilot with the new Assign to Copilot button. This feature makes it easier and faster to start a Copilot assignment with a single click. Pick the target repository: Choose any repository you have access to, even if your issues and code don't live in the same place. Now you can work with Copilot across repositories, so it's easy to start assignments from issues no matter where your code is stored. Pick a starting branch: Choose which branch Copilot should start from. Whether you want Copilot to work off a feature branch, a bug fix branch, or any other starting point, you now have the flexibility to direct Copilot’s work to exactly where you want it. Add additional instructions: Give Copilot more context with optional instructions. You can provide specific guidance, requirements, or extra details to help Copilot understand exactly what you want to accomplish. This makes assignments more precise and helps Copilot deliver results that match your needs. For more details, check out our documentation on assigning Copilot to an issue. 👇 Want to share feedback on this public preview or join the conversation? Please comment below! Disclaimer: The UI for features in public preview is subject to change.

title: Upcoming removal of Copilot premium request $0 budgets for enterprise and team accounts
content: Starting November 18, 2025, GitHub will begin removing all $0 Copilot premium request budgets for enterprise and team accounts created before August 22, 2025. As a result, premium request paid usage will be governed by your account’s premium request paid usage policy, not a static $0 budget. Who is affected? All enterprise and org accounts with an account-level $0 Copilot premium request budget created before August 22, 2025 are affected. Pro and Pro+ Copilot users are not affected and will continue to have $0 budgets by default. Why are we making this change? Enables granular controls without complexity: Starting in October, each AI tool will have their own dedicated SKUs for tracking and managing premium request usage, beginning with coding agent and Spark. Keeping the $0 budget model would require you to manually create and manage separate $0 budgets for each new AI tool, creating unnecessary administrative burden as we expand our AI capabilities. Simplifies billing: Removing this budget option eliminates friction and manual intervention for admins, letting you scale AI usage with confidence. What do you need to do? To control premium request paid usage, review and update your premium request paid usage policy. You can disable paid usage at any time in your Copilot policy settings. Learn more in our documentation on premium requests. Questions For questions, feedback, and any thoughts, please comment in the discussion below!

title: Copilot coding agent is now generally available! 🚀
content: Discussion updated: 09-25-2025 Copilot coding agent, our asynchronous, autonomous developer agent, is now generally available for all paid Copilot subscribers. Delegate a task to Copilot, and Copilot will open a draft pull request and work in the background in its own development environment. It does this through the power of GitHub Actions. Once Copilot is done, it will request a review from you, and you can ask Copilot to make changes by leaving comments on the pull request. GHPadawanWIP01.mp4 Copilot coding agent can complete a wide range of software development tasks including: Implementing new features Fixing bugs Addressing technical debt Improving test coverage Updating documentation There are many ways to hand tasks to Copilot, including assigning it an issue, using the agents panel accessible on every page on GitHub, or using the Delegate to coding agent button in Visual Studio Code. To learn more about Copilot coding agent, head to our documentation. If you're a Copilot Business or Copilot Enterprise subscriber, an administrator will have to enable Copilot coding agent from the "Policies" page before you can use it. Leave a comment 🌟 Let us know your thoughts and feedback below!

title: Manage Copilot and users via Enterprise Teams in public preview
content: 🆕 GitHub Enterprise Cloud now offers Enterprise Teams in public preview, streamlining enterprise user and Copilot license management experiences for businesses. Enterprise owners can now: Add users directly to the enterprise without requiring organization access. These unaffiliated users do not consume a license by default. Create and manage groups of users in the enterprise account through Enterprise Teams. Enterprise accounts with Enterprise Managed Users can synchronize groups of users from their identity provider to Enterprise Teams via SCIM. Manage Copilot Business licenses for individuals or entire enterprise teams through the enterprise-level Copilot licensing page. What Enterprise Teams enable ❓ In the coming months, enterprise owners will also be able to use enterprise teams to: Assign an enterprise role. Assign it to a number of organizations within that enterprise, granting organization membership. Empower organization and repository owners to assign roles to teams within their scope. Unaffiliated users (non-EMU enterprises) 👀 For enterprises that do not use enterprise-managed users (EMU), enterprise owners can now invite unaffiliated users to their enterprise. These users will not have access to organizations or licenses by default, but can later be assigned to an enterprise team, an organization, or Copilot Business license. If a user is removed from all organizations, they will remain in the enterprise as an unaffiliated user unless the remove from enterprise action is taken. Since users may not be automatically removed from your enterprise, we recommend reviewing your offboarding process to ensure it accounts for this change. Copilot Business licensing updates 💼 Along with enterprise teams and unaffiliated users now being available to all enterprises, updates have been made to Copilot Business licensing. Enterprise owners can use a dedicated Copilot Business licensing page to assign users and enterprise teams. These updates provide more flexible and scalable license management for enterprises, including the ability to assign Copilot Business to users without also requiring a GitHub Enterprise Cloud license. Join us in the comments below to share your feedback and ask questions. 👇 Learn more To learn more, check out our documentation on Enterprise Teams, unaffiliated users, and Copilot Business licensing. If you have feedback about these new features, join us on this discussion. ⚠️ Disclaimer: The UI for features in public preview is subject to change.

title: 🚀 Now available: Copilot Spaces — A new way to work with context
content: Ever wish Copilot understood your project as well as your teammates do? Now it can. With Copilot Spaces, you can bring together the context Copilot needs (e.g. files, pull requests, issues, repos) into "Spaces". The result? Copilot gives you responses that are grounded in the right context for a specific task. Create a space Organize code, files, pull requests, issues and other project context into a space. Add custom instructions to help guide responses. We’ve made some adjustments to how Copilot works with context in Spaces, so context groundedness should be very high. Context is always based on the latest state of your main branch. Files and repositories added to a space are always kept up to date as they change, making Copilot an evergreen expert in your project. Chat with a space Ask Copilot questions grounded in the context of your Space for more accurate and relevant answers. Share it with teammates You can share spaces with other members of your organization. Spaces in the IDE Access your Space context directly from supported IDEs through the remote GitHub MCP Server. 📂 Do more with Spaces and use it to: Generate code Share knowledge Plan projects Some of our favorite use cases ⭐ Answering questions about code: Chris Westra is an engineer on the Spaces team. He grouped all of the code associated with Spaces and added video transcripts from a recorded Spaces session. We use this Space to answer questions about how Spaces works under-the-hood (very meta). 🙂 Standardizing coding standards and best practices: Rahul Zhade works on a team that advises engineers on secure coding practices. He often answers the same questions over-and-over again in Slack, so he set up a Space. It contains the documentation for our standard auth model, how to do cryptography as well as instructions on how to go through the security review process. Writing SQL/KQL queries: Kelly Henckel is a product manager who is very good at writing SQL and KQL queries. She’s created spaces designed to help people self-service writing data queries and creating dashboards. These helpers contain the code for our telemetry schemas as well as example queries. Updating documentation: Holly Kassel is a product manager working on billing and licensing. She’s been updating GitHub’s documentation to be more user-friendly based on questions arriving through our customer support channels and discussion posts. She creates spaces for each new batch of documentation which needs to be updated, links the existing code and documentation hosted in GitHub, and adds instructions and frequently asked questions as context. The space generates updated versions of the documentation which can be easily copied into our docs repo. Please share feedback with us 🤝 We appreciate your feedback. Give Spaces a try and let us know what you think either in this discussion post or through the inline feedback button. 🚀 Try Spaces now Learn more about Spaces: Changelog Documentation Microsoft Learn module - Introduction to Spaces GitHub Skills exercise

title: [Preview] MCP Server Support in GitHub.com
content: 👋 Welcome to the discussion for MCP Server Support—a new capability in GitHub.com! With MCP servers, Copilot can leverage external information sources (like Atlassian, Notion, Sentry, Linear, and more) to provide richer, more contextual responses in GitHub. Join the preview This feature is available in private preview. ➡️ Sign up for the preview here Key Features ✨ Integrate External Tools: Add MCP servers to connect Copilot with external sources for code, docs, design files, issue trackers, monitoring, and more. Flexible & Open: Supported integrations include both official and open-source servers. Servers must be remotely hosted, support SSE/Streamable HTTP, and comply with OAuth 2.1. Contextual Intelligence: Copilot intelligently invokes tools provided by your MCP servers based on your chat requests and each tool’s description. Security First: Only install servers you trust. Info shared with external servers may include proprietary data—review access and permissions before connecting. Favorite Use Cases ⭐ Project Management Integration: Bring in issues and tasks from Jira so Copilot can answer project-related questions and automate workflows. Documentation & Knowledge Base: Integrate Notion or Confluence so Copilot can reference up-to-date docs, onboarding guides, and FAQs. Monitoring & Alerts: Use Sentry integration to discuss error reports, incidents, and troubleshooting steps in context. Custom Workflows: Leverage open-source MCP servers for niche tools, internal systems, or personalized automation. Getting Started Go to github.com/copilot Select Tools > New Tool Enter your server URL and complete authentication, if required Start chatting with Copilot—now powered by your external sources! To remove a server, visit github.com/settings/mcp. Important Security Notice ⚠️ Only install MCP servers you trust. Do not install servers on accounts with sensitive/confidential info unless sharing is explicitly permitted. GitHub assumes no responsibility for data sent to external servers. Please Share Feedback 🤝 This is an early preview, and your feedback is vital! Try adding a MCP Server and let us know what you think—comment below or use the inline feedback button. We’re excited to see what you build! 🚀

title: Copilot generated commit messages on github.com is in public preview
content: GitHub Copilot now offers contextual commit message suggestions for github.com file changes, making documentation an effortless part of your workflow. With this enhancement, Copilot automatically suggests a concise summary of changes made through the file editor on github.com. Deleting a file continues to use the existing default: Delete <filename> Adding a new file without any contents continues to use the existing default: Add <filename> commitmessagedemo2.mp4 Availability and usage Copilot commit message generation is available to all public preview enabled paid Copilot subscribers. It does not consume usage quota. Enabling the feature for organizations and enterprises Organizations and enterprises can enable this and other features in public preview by selecting Opt in to preview features in the Copilot in github.com setting. If your Enterprise has rulesets for commit metadata enabled, you will still see a default commit message in commits made in organization-related files. This feature is also available in GitHub Enterprise Cloud with data residency. Share your feedback ➡️ Give us feedback on this feature or let us know what you think in the comments below!

title: Premium request overage policy is generally available for Copilot Business and Enterprise
content: GitHub is introducing a premium request overage policy for GitHub Copilot Business and GitHub Copilot Enterprise customers. This will provide you with simplified control over how your enterprise or organization handles premium request usage beyond your account's included usage. What's changing Instead of an automatically-created $0 budget that blocks usage when your premium requests are exhausted, you can now manage overages through a dedicated policy in your Copilot settings. The policy offers you two options: Enabled (default) - Allow charges for usage beyond your account's included premium requests Disabled - Block usage when your included premium requests are exhausted If you have an existing $0 premium request budget in your account, it will not be removed. You can remove or modify this budget at any time. What's not changing Copilot for individuals (Pro/Pro+) plans are not affected at this time. If you have a premium request budget in your account, it remains unchanged. Your included premium requests and seat pricing remain the same. Your current budgets continue to work as before. Learn more Managing your Copilot premium request policy About billing for GitHub Copilot Have feedback or questions? Join us below in the comments to share feedback and tips.
